51.text: Thank you.  And thank you, Lucie (?).

54.text: I cannot wait to see what we are going to all do together.

57.text:
This is going to be so exciting!
[Applause]

64.text: Just so you all know, the hurricane has hit landfall and I think we should take this moment

69.text: and recognize that fellow Americans are in its path

73.text: and just hope and pray that all remain safe and no life is lost and no property is lost.

81.text: So we should all be thankful for this great country and grateful for our first responders

86.text:
and all that keep us safe in this wonderful country.
[Applause]

98.text: Well, I want to talk to you tonight not about politics and not about party.

105.text: And while there are many important issues that we will hear discussed

109.text: in this convention and throughout this campaign

112.text: tonight, I want to talk to you from my heart about our hearts. [Applause]

126.text: I want to talk about not what divides us, but what holds us together as an American family.

132.text: I want to talk to you tonight about that one great thing that unites us, that one great thing

139.text: that brings us our greatest joy when times are good and the deepest solace in our dark hours.

146.text: Tonight, I want to talk to you about love.

152.text: I want to talk to you about the deep and abiding love I have for a man I met at a dance many years ago,

160.text: and the profound love I have and I know we share for this country.

166.text: I want to talk to you about that love so deep, only a mother can fathom it:

172.text: the love that we have for our children and our children's children.

177.text: And I want us to think tonight about the love we share for those Americans,

183.text: our brothers and our sisters, who are going through difficult times,

188.text: whose days are never easy, nights are always long, and whose work never seems done.

194.text: They're here among us tonight in this hall.

197.text: They are here in neighborhoods across Tampa and all across America.

201.text: The parents who lie awake at night, side by side, wondering how

204.text: they will be able to pay the mortgage or make the rent.

207.text: The single dad who is working extra hours tonight

209.text: so that his kids can buy some new clothes to go back to school,

213.text: can take a school trip or play a sport so his kids can feel, you know, just like other kids.

221.text: And the working moms who love their jobs,

224.text: but would like to work just a little less to spend more time with the kids,

228.text: but that is just out of the question with this economy.

230.text: Or how about that couple who would like to have another child but wonder how they will afford it?

236.text: I have been all across this country and I know a lot of you guys. [Applause]

251.text: And I have seen and heard stories of how hard it is to get ahead now.

256.text: You know what?  I have heard your voices.

260.text: They have said to me, I am running in place and we just cannot get ahead.

266.text: Sometimes, I think that, late at night, if we were all silent for just a few moments and listened carefully,

273.text: we could hear a collective sigh from the moms and dads across America

277.text: who made it through another day, and know that they will make it through another one tomorrow.

282.text: But in the end of that day moment, they are just aren't sure how.

286.text: And if you listen carefully, you'll hear the women sighing a little bit more than the men.

293.text: It's how it is, isn't it?

296.text: It's the moms who have always had to work a little harder to make everything right.

300.text: It's the mom's of this nation, single, married, widowed, who really hold the country together.

306.text: We're the mothers.   We're the wives.  We're the grandmothers.  We're the big sisters.

312.text: We're the little sisters and we are the daughters.

315.text:
You know it's true, don't you?
[Applause]

337.text:
Those are my favorite fans down there.
[Applause]

341.text: You are the ones that have to do a little bit more and you know

345.text: what it is like to earn a little bit harder earn the respect you deserve at work

349.text: and then you come home at night and help with the book report just because it has to be done.

354.text: You know what those late-night phone calls with an elderly parent are like,

357.text: and the long weekend drives just to see how they're doing.

360.text: You know the fastest route to the local emergency room

362.text: and which doctors actually answers the phone call

365.text: when you call at night, and by the way, I know all about that.

368.text: You know what it is like to sit in that graduation ceremony and wonder how it was

373.text: that so many long days turned into years that went by so quickly.

378.text:
You are the best of America. You
[Applause]

389.text: You are the hope of America.  There would not be an America without you.

395.text:
Tonight, we salute you and sing your praises!
[Applause]

408.text: I'm not sure if men really understand this,

411.text: but I don't think there is a woman in America who really expects her life to be easy.

417.text: In our own ways, we all know better.

419.text: You know what, and that's fine. We don't want easy.

423.text: But the last few years have been harder than they needed to be.

425.text: It is all the little things, the price of the pump you just can't believe

429.text: the grocery bills that just get bigger,

431.text: all those things that used to be free, like school sports are now one more bill to pay.

436.text: It's all the little things that pile up to become the big things.

439.text: And the big things, the good jobs, the chance at college, that home you want to buy just get harder.

447.text: We're too smart to know there aren't easy answers,

450.text: but we're not dumb enough to accept that there aren't better answers. [Applause]

467.text: And that is where this boy I met at a high school dance comes in.

473.text: His name is Mitt Romney and you should really get to know him. [Applause]

482.text: I could tell you why I fell in love with him; he was tall, laughed a lot.

485.text: He was nervous.  Girls like that.  It shows the guy's a little intimidated.

490.text: He was nice to my parents, but he was also really glad when they weren't around.

496.text: I don't mind that.  But more than anything, he made me laugh.

501.text: Some of you might not know this, but I am the granddaughter of a Welsh coal miner.

508.text: He was determined -- he was determined that his kids get out of the mines.

513.text: My dad got his first job when he was six years old in a little village in Wales called (inaudible),

520.text: cleaning bottles at the Carew's Arms' (?).

523.text: When he was 15, Dad came to America.

525.text: In our country, he saw hope and an opportunity to escape from poverty.

531.text: He moved to a small town in the great state of Michigan [Applause]

544.text: There he started a business, one he built by himself, by the way. [Applause]

555.text: He raised a family and he became mayor of our town.

559.text: My dad would often remind my brothers and me how fortunate we were to grow up anyplace like America.

565.text: He wanted us to have every opportunity that came with life in this country,

569.text: and so he pushed us to be our best and give our all.

572.text: Inside the houses that line the streets of our town,

575.text: there were a lot of fathers teaching their sons and daughters those same values.

579.text: I didn't know it at the time, but one of those dads was my future father-in-law, George Romney.

590.text: Mitt's dad never graduated from college.  Instead, he became a carpenter.

594.text: He worked hard, he became the head of the car company, and then the governor of Michigan.

598.text: When Mitt and I met and fell in love,

600.text: we were determined not to let anything stand in a way of our life together.

604.text: I was Episcopalian, he was a Mormon.  We were very young, both still in college.

610.text: There were many reasons to delay marriage.  And you know what, we just didn't care.

615.text: We got married and moved into a basement apartment. [Applause]

625.text: We walked to class together, shared the housekeeping, ate a lot of pasta and tuna fish.

631.text: Our desk was a door propped up on saw horses,

635.text: our dining room table was a fold down ironing board in the kitchen.

639.text: But those were the best days.

643.text: Then our first son came along.  All at once, I'm 22-years-old with a  baby and a husband,

649.text: who's going to business school and law school at the same time,

652.text: and I can tell you, probably like every other girl

655.text: who finds herself in a new life far from family and friends with a new baby and a new husband,

660.text: that it dawned on me that I had absolutely no idea what I was getting into. [Laughter]

669.text: Well that was 42 years ago.  I've survived.

671.text: We now have five sons and 18 beautiful grandchildren. [Applause]

685.text: I'm still in love with that boy that I met at a high school dance and he still makes me laugh. [Applause]

696.text: I read somewhere that Mitt and I have a storybook marriage. Well, let me tell you something.

701.text: In the storybooks I read, there never were long, long rainy winter afternoons

707.text:
in a house with five boys screaming at once,
[Laughter]

711.text: and those storybooks never seemed to have chapter's called M.S. or breast cancer.

717.text: A storybook marriage?  Nope, not at all.

720.text:
What Mitt Romney and I have is a real marriage.
[Applause]

741.text: I know this good and decent man for what he is.  He's warm, and loving, and patient.

746.text: He has tried to live his life with a set of values centered on family, faith,

751.text: and love of one's fellow man.

753.text: From the time we were first married, I have seen him spend countless hours helping others.

758.text: I've seen him drop everything to help a friend in trouble, and being there

762.text: when late-night calls of panic come from a member of our church

765.text: whose child has been taken to the hospital.

768.text: You may not agree on Mitt's positions on issues or his politics --

771.text: by the way Massachusetts is only 13 percent Republican, so it's not like it's a shock to me.

778.text: But -- but let me say this to every American who is thinking about who should be our next president.

788.text: No one will work harder.  No one will care more.

794.text: And no one will move heaven and earth like Mitt Romney to make this country a better place to live.

838.text: It's true -- it's true that Mitt's been successful at each new challenge he has taken on.

846.text: You know what, it actually amazes me to see his history of success being attacked.

851.text: Are those really the values that made our country great?

856.text: [Ann Romney]  As a mom of five boys, do we want to to raise our children to be afraid of success?

863.text: [Ann Romney]  Do we send our children out in the world with the advice try to do OK?

870.text: [Ann Romney]  And let's be honest: if the last four years had been more successful,

873.text: do we really think there would be this attack on Mitt Romney's success?

879.text: [Ann Romney]  Of course not.  Mitt would be the first to tell you that he is the most fortunate man in the world.

884.text: He had two loving parents who gave him strong values and taught him the value of work.

889.text: He had the chance to get the education his father never had.

893.text: But, as his partner on this amazing journey, I can tell you Mitt Romney was not handed success.

929.text: He stayed in Massachusetts after graduate school and got a job.

933.text: I saw the long hours that started with that first job.

936.text: I was there when he had a small group of friends talking about starting a new company.

940.text: I was there when they struggled and wondered if the whole idea was just not going to work.

946.text: Mitt's reaction was to work harder and press on.

951.text: Today, the company has become another great American success story.

955.text: Has it made those who started the company successful

959.text: -- made them successful beyond their dreams?

962.text: It allowed us to give our sons a chance at good educations and made

966.text: all those long hours of the reports and homework worth every minute.

969.text: It's given us the deep satisfaction of being able

972.text: to help others in ways that we could never have imagined.

977.text: This is important.  I want you to hear what I am going to say.

982.text: Mitt does not like to talk about how he has helped others

985.text: because he sees it as a privilege, not a political talking point.

1010.text: We are no different than the millions of Americans

1013.text: who quietly help their neighbors, their churches and their communities.

1017.text: They don't do it so that others will think more of them.

1021.text: They do it because there is no greater joy.

1026.text:
Give and it shall be given unto you.
[Applause]

1039.text: But because this is America, that small company which grew has helped so many lead better lives,

1044.text: the jobs that grew from the risk they took have become college educations and first homes.

1050.text: That success has helped fund scholarships, pensions and retirement funds.

1054.text: This is the genius of America.

1058.text:
Dreams fulfilled, help others launch new dreams.
[Applause]

1070.text: At every turn in his life, this man that I met at a high school dance has helped lift up others.

1076.text: He did it with the Olympics when many wanted to give up.

1080.text: He did it in Massachusetts where he guided the state

1082.text: from economic crisis to unemployment at just 4.7 percent.

1087.text: Under Mitt, Massachusetts' schools were the best in the nation.

1097.text: He started something that I really love.

1099.text: He started the John and Abigail Adams scholarship

1102.text: which gives the top 25 percent of high- school graduates

1114.text:
This is the man America needs.
[Applause]

1121.text: This is a man who will wake up every day with the determination

1125.text: to solve the problems that others say cannot be solved,

1127.text: to fix what others say is beyond repair,

1130.text: this is the man who will work harder than anyone so that we can work a little less hard.

1136.text: I can't tell you what will happen over the next four years.

1138.text: But I can only stand here tonight as a wife and a mother and a grandmother, an American,

1144.text: and make you this solemn commitment.

1176.text: This man will not let us down. This man will lift up America.

1183.text: It has been 47 years since that tall, kind of charming young man, brought me home from our first dance.

1189.text: Not everyday since has been easy, but he still makes me laugh

1194.text: and never once did I have a single reason to doubt that I was the luckiest woman in the world tonight.

1199.text: I said tonight I wanted to talk to you about love.

1203.text: Look into your hearts. This is our country. This is our future.

1212.text: These are our children and grandchildren.

1232.text: He loves America. He will take us to a better place,

1237.text: just as he took me home safely from that dance.

1241.text: Give him that chance. Give America that chance.

1246.text: God bless each and everyone of you and God bless the United States of America. [Applause and cheers]
